documents.title: Documents
documents.content:
### Passport
Your passport must be valid for the duration of your stay (no 6-month extra validity requirement) [overseas.mofa.go.kr](https://overseas.mofa.go.kr).

### Visa/K-ETA
Citizens of about 112 countries (including the US, EU, UK, etc.) can enter visa-free for short visits (typically 90 days). An electronic travel authorization (K-ETA) is normally required for visa-free visitors (fee ~10,000 KRW, valid 3 years) [visasnews.com](https://visasnews.com/k-eta-south-korea-electronic-travel-authorization/). Note: until Dec 31, 2025, travelers from 67 major countries are temporarily exempt from K-ETA. Those needing a visa (for work, study, long stays) must apply at a Korean consulate.

### Customs
Duty-free allowances include about US$800 in goods per traveler, plus up to 2L liquor and 200 cigarettes [customs.go.kr](https://www.customs.go.kr/english/main.do). Declare any cash >US$10,000 on arrival [english.visitkorea.or.kr](https://english.visitkorea.or.kr/svc/main/index.do). Prohibited items (drugs, unlicensed weapons, counterfeit goods) are strictly forbidden [customs.go.kr](https://www.customs.go.kr/english/main.do).

culture.title: Culture & Etiquette
culture.content:
### Respect & Hierarchy
Korean culture is rooted in Confucian values – respect for elders/superiors and harmony are paramount [english.visitseoul.net](https://english.visitseoul.net/index). Bowing (a slight nod) is a common greeting, often combined with a gentle handshake (use both hands for handshakes and when receiving items).

### Shoes
Always remove shoes when entering a home, temple, or traditional guesthouse [english.visitseoul.net](https://english.visitseoul.net/index).

### Dining Etiquette
Wait for the eldest person to begin eating before you start [english.visitseoul.net](https://english.visitseoul.net/index). Don’t stick chopsticks upright in rice (it resembles a funeral rite).

### Tipping
Not customary in Korea [english.visitseoul.net](https://english.visitseoul.net/index). Paying the bill is sufficient.

### Holidays
Seollal (Lunar New Year, Jan/Feb) and Chuseok (Mid-Autumn Harvest Festival, Sept/Oct) are the two biggest traditional holidays [ltl-school.com](https://ltl-school.com/korean/holidays-in-korea/). Many businesses and transport services have limited hours during these times.

safety.title: Safety
safety.content:
### General Safety
South Korea is very safe for travelers [travelnoire.com](https://travelnoire.com/is-south-korea-safe-for-travelers). Violent crime against foreigners is rare and overall crime rates are low. Urban areas (Seoul, Busan, etc.) are well-policed and well-lit. Petty theft is uncommon but can occur in crowded places.

### Emergencies
Dial 112 for police and 119 for fire/ambulance [travel.state.gov](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/International-Travel-Country-Information-Pages/SouthKorea.html).

### Scams
Tourist scams exist but are not pervasive. Reported schemes include overstated bills at “tea ceremonies” or unlicensed vendors selling fake luxury goods [travelnoire.com](https://travelnoire.com/is-south-korea-safe-for-travelers). Use reputable businesses and metered taxis (or the Kakao T app).

### Protests & DMZ
Demonstrations occasionally occur in Seoul. They are usually peaceful, but it's best to avoid large crowds. The border (DMZ) region is heavily restricted; only visit on official guided tours [travel.state.gov](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/International-Travel-Country-Information-Pages/SouthKorea.html).

health.title: Health
health.content:
### Vaccinations
Stay up-to-date on routine immunizations. The CDC also recommends hepatitis A and typhoid vaccines for South Korea [passporthealthusa.com](https://www.passporthealthusa.com/destination-advice/south-korea/). Japanese Encephalitis vaccination is recommended if you’ll spend lots of time in rural areas between May–Oct.

### Healthcare System
South Korea’s medical facilities are modern and high-quality. Doctors in major hospitals often speak basic English. Healthcare can be costly for visitors, so comprehensive travel health insurance is strongly recommended [travel.state.gov](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/International-Travel-Country-Information-Pages/SouthKorea.html).

### Water & Food
Tap water in South Korea is generally safe to drink, though many locals and visitors prefer bottled water [travelnoire.com](https://travelnoire.com/is-south-korea-safe-for-travelers). Street food is popular; practice normal food safety (eat hot food, wash hands).

money.title: Money
money.content:
### Currency
The won (KRW) is the unit. As of 2025, ₩1,000 ≈ $0.75. ATMs are widely available and many accept international cards.

### Payment Methods
Credit/debit cards are widely accepted throughout urban areas [travelnoire.com](https://travelnoire.com/is-south-korea-safe-for-travelers). Always carry some cash for small vendors or markets. For cashless purchases and transit, buy a T-money card – it can be used on subways, buses, taxis, and at convenience stores [whatsdavedoing.com](https://whatsdavedoing.com/t-money-card-korea/).

### Cost of Living
South Korea can be moderately expensive. A casual meal is about ₩5,000–10,000. Budget roughly ₩30,000–50,000 ($25–40) per day for food per person. Hostels start from ~$15, while 3-star hotels are ~$50–100 per night [tripwis.com](https://tripwis.com/cost-of-travel-in-south-korea/).

### Tipping
Not expected.

connectivity.title: Connectivity
connectivity.content:
### Internet & Wi-Fi
South Korea has top-tier telecom infrastructure. Free Wi-Fi is extremely common (airports, subways, buses, cafes) [whatsdavedoing.com](https://whatsdavedoing.com/getting-connected-in-south-korea/). For continuous access, get a local SIM or eSIM.

### SIM/eSIM
Tourist SIM cards are sold at Incheon Airport and city shops. The main carriers are SK Telecom, KT, and LG U+. Unlimited data packages cost about ₩36,500 (~$25) for ~10 days [whatsdavedoing.com](https://whatsdavedoing.com/getting-connected-in-south-korea/).

### Apps
- **Navigation:** Naver Map and KakaoMap are far more reliable than Google Maps.
- **Translation:** Naver Papago is a powerful translation app.
- **Messaging:** KakaoTalk is the dominant messaging app.
- **Taxis:** KakaoT is the go-to app for summoning taxis.

adaptation.title: Adaptation
adaptation.content:
### Transportation
South Korea’s public transit is world-class. Get a T-money card for seamless travel on subways, buses, and taxis [whatsdavedoing.com](https://whatsdavedoing.com/t-money-card-korea/). Major city subways have English signage and announcements. For intercity travel, high-speed trains (KTX) are efficient.

### Weather & Clothing
Korea has four distinct seasons [selectiveasia.com](https://www.selectiveasia.com/south-korea-holidays/weather).
- **Spring (Mar–May) & Autumn (Sept–Nov):** Pleasant and mild. Peak times to visit.
- **Summer (Jul–Aug):** Hot and humid, with monsoon rains.
- **Winter (Dec–Feb):** Cold, especially in the north, with occasional snow.

### Basic Korean Phrases
- **Hello:** 안녕하세요 (annyeonghaseyo)
- **Thank you:** 감사합니다 (gamsahamnida)
- **Yes / No:** 네 (ne) / 아닙니다 (animnida)
- **Excuse me / Sorry:** 실례합니다 (shillyehamnida)
